Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Analgesic Strategies After Open Liver Resection

Trial_Design.evidence: In this single-centre trial, 186 adult patients undergoing open liver resection at the University Hospital of Lille, France, were randomly assigned in a 1:1:1 ratio

Participants.evidence: 186 adult patients undergoing open liver resection at the University Hospital of Lille, France

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned in a 1:1:1 ratio to receive i.v. analgesia alone, i.v. analgesia with CWI, or i.v. analgesia with ITM

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated the efficacy of intravenous (i.v.) analgesia alone or combined with catheter wound infusion (CWI) or intrathecal morphine (ITM).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the cumulative morphine dose at 24 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using sealed envelopes with a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was open-label.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 186 patients were randomised and analysed (62 per group) between May 2015 and December 2020.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 186 patients were randomised and analysed (62 per group)

Result_Outcome.evidence: ITM significantly reduced morphine use compared to i.v. analgesia alone (mean difference on log-transformed values 0.57; 95% CI 0.21 to 0.93; P = 0.002).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events and postoperative complications were comparable across the three groups.
